markdown_text: **Pricing Term Sheet – 1.966% Senior Notes due 2019** Issuer: Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation (“SMBC”) Guarantor: The New York branch of SMBC (the “Branch”) Securities Offered: U.S.$750,000,000 aggregate principal amount of 1.966% senior notes due 2019 (the “Notes”), unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by the Branch Offer and Sale: Exempt from registration with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission pursuant to Section 3(a)(2) of the U.S. Securities Act of 1933, as amended Expected Security Ratings*:A1 (Moody’s) / A (S&P) Denomination: U.S.$250,000 and integral multiples of U.S.$1,000 in excess thereof Offering Price: 100% Pricing Date: January 5, 2017 Settlement Date**: January 12, 2017 Maturity Date: January 11, 2019 Redemption: The Notes will only be redeemable at SMBC’s option upon the occurrence of certain changes in tax law, as set forth in the base offering circular dated October 11, 2016, as supplemented by the supplement dated January 5, 2017 Ranking of the Notes: The Notes will be direct, unconditional, unsubordinated and unsecured obligations of SMBC and will at all times rank pari passu among themselves and with all other unsecured obligations of SMBC other than subordinated obligations (except for statutorily preferred obligations) Guarantee: The Notes will be unconditionally and irrevocably guaranteed by the Branch. The guarantee will be a direct, unconditional, irrevocable, unsecured and unsubordinated obligation of the Branch and will at all times rank pari passu in right of payment with all other unsecured, unsubordinated obligations of the Branch (except for statutorily preferred obligations) Interest Rate and Payment Dates: 1.966%, payable semiannually in arrears on January 11 and July 11 of each year beginning on July 11, 2017. Such semiannual interest will amount to U.S.$9.78 per each U.S.$1,000 in nominal amount of the Notes for the first interest payment date on July 11, 2017 and will amount to U.S.$9.83 per each U.S.$1,000 in nominal amount of the Notes for each interest payment date thereafter Day Count Basis: 30/360, unadjusted Business Day: New York, London and Tokyo Cross Default: The Notes will contain a cross default in respect of any indebtedness for borrowed money having a total principal amount then outstanding of at least U.S.$100,000,000 Use of Proceeds: General corporate purposes Listing: Singapore Exchange Securities Trading Limited Resale Restrictions: None Settlement: DTC, Euroclear and Clearstream CUSIP: 865622 CE2 ISIN: US865622CE22 ----- Common Code: 154299629 Joint Lead Managers and Joint Bookrunners: Goldman, Sachs & Co. SMBC Nikko Securities America, Inc. Citigroup Global Markets Inc. J.P. Morgan Securities LLC Co-Managers: Barclays Capital Inc. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Incorporated Nomura Securities International, Inc. Daiwa Capital Markets America Inc. HSBC Securities (USA) Inc. Natixis Securities Americas LLC RBC Capital Markets, LLC Standard Chartered Bank Wells Fargo Securities, LLC Stabilization Manager: SMBC Nikko Securities America, Inc. Paying Agent: Citibank, N.A., London - A security rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time by the assigning rating agencies. ** T+5 on January 12, 2017. SMBC expects that delivery of the Notes will be made against payment therefor on or about January 12, 2017, which is the fifth New York business day following the date of pricing of the Notes. Under Rule 15c6-1 of the U.S. Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, trades in the secondary market generally are required to settle in three business days unless the parties to any such trade expressly agree otherwise. Accordingly, purchasers who wish to trade the Notes on the date of pricing of the Notes or the next succeeding business day will be required, by virtue of the fact that the Notes initially will settle five New York business days after pricing of the Notes, to specify an alternate settlement cycle at the time of any such trade to prevent failed settlement and should consult their own advisers. January 5, 2017 -----
